t: Isaiah 14
The Restoration of Jacob
For*p the Lord*s will have compassion on Jacob and will again choose Israel, and will set them in their own land, and sojourners will join them and will attach themselves to the house of Jacob.

And the peoples will take them and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel will possess them in the Lord’s*s land as male and female slaves. They will take captive those who were their captors, and rule over those who oppressed them.
Israel’s Remnant Taunts Babylon
When*p the Lord*s has given you rest from your pain and turmoil and the hard service with which you were made to serve,
you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon: “How*pn the oppressor has ceased, the*ld insolent fury ceased!
The*ln Lord*s has broken the staff of the wicked, the*ld scepter of rulers,
that*ln struck the peoples in wrath with*ld unceasing blows, that*ln ruled the nations in anger with*ld unrelenting persecution.
The*ln whole earth is at rest and quiet; they*ld break forth into singing.
The*ln cypresses rejoice at you, the*ld cedars of Lebanon, saying, ‘Since*ln you were laid low, no*ld woodcutter comes up against us.’

Sheol*ln beneath is stirred up to*ld meet you when you come; it*ln rouses the shades to greet you, all*ld who were leaders of the earth; it*ln raises from their thrones all*ld who were kings of the nations.
All*ln of them will answer and*ld say to you: ‘You*ln too have become as weak as we! You*ld have become like us!’
Your*ln pomp is brought down to Sheol, the*ld sound of your harps; maggots*ln are laid as a bed beneath you, and*ld worms are your covers.
“How*pn you are fallen from heaven, O*ld Day Star, son of Dawn! How*ln you are cut down to the ground, you*ld who laid the nations low!
You*ln said in your heart, ‘I*ld will ascend to heaven; above*ln the stars of God I*ld will set my throne on high; I*ln will sit on the mount of assembly in*ld the far reaches of the north;
I*ln will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I*ld will make myself like the Most High.’
But*ln you are brought down to Sheol, to*ld the far reaches of the pit.
Those*ln who see you will stare at you and*ld ponder over you: ‘Is*ln this the man who made the earth tremble, who*ld shook kingdoms,
who*ln made the world like a desert and*ld overthrew its cities, who*ld did not let his prisoners go home?’
All*ln the kings of the nations lie in glory, each*ld in his own tomb;

but*ln you are cast out, away from your grave, like*ld a loathed branch, clothed*ln with the slain, those pierced by the sword, who*ld go down to the stones of the pit, like*ld a dead body trampled underfoot.
You*ln will not be joined with them in burial, because*ld you have destroyed your land, you*ld have slain your people. “May*pn the offspring of evildoers nevermore*ld be named!
Prepare*ln slaughter for his sons because*ld of the guilt of their fathers, lest*ln they rise and possess the earth, and*ld fill the face of the world with cities.”
“I*p will rise up against them,” declares the Lord*s of hosts, “and will cut off from Babylon name and remnant, descendants and posterity,” declares the Lord.*s
“And I will make it a possession of the hedgehog, and pools of water, and I will sweep it with the broom of destruction,” declares the Lord*s of hosts.
An Oracle Concerning Assyria
The*pn Lord*s of hosts has sworn: “As*ln I have planned, so*ld shall it be, and*ln as I have purposed, so*ld shall it stand,
that*ln I will break the Assyrian in my land, and*ld on my mountains trample him underfoot; and*ln his yoke shall depart from them, and*ld his burden from their shoulder.”
This*pn is the purpose that is purposed concerning*ld the whole earth, and*ln this is the hand that is stretched out over*ld all the nations.
For*ln the Lord*s of hosts has purposed, and*ld who will annul it? His*ln hand is stretched out, and*ld who will turn it back?
An Oracle Concerning Philistia
In*p the year that King Ahaz died came this oracle:
Rejoice*pn not, O Philistia, all of you, that*ld the rod that struck you is broken, for*ln from the serpent’s root will come forth an adder, and*ld its fruit will be a flying fiery serpent.
And*ln the firstborn of the poor will graze, and*ld the needy lie down in safety; but*ln I will kill your root with famine, and*ld your remnant it will slay.
Wail,*ln O gate; cry out, O city; melt*ld in fear, O Philistia, all of you! For*ln smoke comes out of the north, and*ld there is no straggler in his ranks.
What*pn will one answer the messengers of the nation? “The*ln Lord*s has founded Zion, and*ld in her the afflicted of his people find refuge.”
